channel.title: Bootchart! How long does YOUR system take to boot?
channel.description:
I discovered this nifty little package browsing the Archlinux forums. You add "init=/sbin/bootchartd" to your startup in grub and when you log in you run the command "bootchart-render" and it generates this detailed chart on how long it took your system to boot and where/what is taking how long to load.
My bootchart: [IMG]http://i116.photobucket.com/albums/o26/photos_r_me/bootchart.png[/img]
28secs right now but I only changed a couple things before I tried this, bet I can get it lower :P
I wanna compare to some people here...how long does it take [i][b]your[/b][/i] system to boot? See if you can bet me :D
Shouldn't be that hard.
*Note* Plus I'm at a disadvantage here..I only got a Pentium 4 :( (for now!)

item.title: Bootchart! How long does YOUR system take to boot?
item.dc:creator: @llib llib
item.description:
@llib wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:19, topic:215230”]Sh is like, a shitty old shell that bash superceded.

You could prolly just symlink /bin/sh to /bin/bash (with ln -s) and it would work.[/quote]

Yea just checked, the file /bin/sh is a link to bash. So if he links it, it should work…

Edit:
Learn somethin everyday…

Read full topic
item.source: Bootchart! How long does YOUR system take to boot?

item.title: Bootchart! How long does YOUR system take to boot?
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Sh is like, a shitty old shell that bash superceded.

You could prolly just symlink /bin/sh to /bin/bash (with ln -s) and it would work.

Read full topic
item.source: Bootchart! How long does YOUR system take to boot?

item.title: Bootchart! How long does YOUR system take to boot?
item.dc:creator: @llib llib
item.description:
@llib wrote:

Mopman:

Uh, sh != bash.

Well I typed pacman -S sh

and it told me it was going to reinstall bash…

[quote=“bowserjr2, post:17, topic:215230”][quote author=llib link=topic=282913.msg2299746#msg2299746 date=1214549942]
You don’t have bash installed?

Go through synaptic and check that…also check if you have a file called “bootchart.tgz” in /var/log/

If that file isn’t being made you have a problem.
[/quote]
bootchart.tgz is not there.
But a empty map called bootchart is there.[/quote]
hmm…since your using Ubuntu your probably using gdm, but what login manager are you using?

And did you try installing bash/sh through synaptic?

Read full topic

item.title: Bootchart! How long does YOUR system take to boot?
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

For some reason I assumed the output of the failed start would be in dmesg, but it wasn’t, meh.

You could try installing sh with your package manager, if it wants sh.

Read full topic
item.source: Bootchart! How long does YOUR system take to boot?

item.title: Bootchart! How long does YOUR system take to boot?
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

[quote=“llib, post:12, topic:215230”][quote author=bowserjr2 link=topic=282913.msg2298928#msg2298928 date=1214523992]

I believe its a kernel option, so move it up there:

title Ubuntu hardy BOOTCHART root (hd0,1) kernel /boot/vmlinuz-2.6.24-12-generic root=UUID=0df3774e-5eaf-4cbd-9871-5f3a28048ddd ro quiet splash locale=nb_NO init=/sbin/bootchartd initrd /boot/initrd.img-2.6.24-12-generic

I tested it, but the command: bootchart-render did not work.
[/quote]

What was the error message that you were given?

Edit:
I’ve dropped it down to 21, I really don’t know what else I can do, I’m practically at a wall here, I’m going through rc.sysinit and removeing checks I don’t need.

I think if I wanted to lose more time I’d have to compile my own kernel with all the modules I need added into it. From what I’ve heard compiling a custom kernel isn’t exactly something you do for fun either.

Although I’ll probably end up doing it anyway >.>[/quote]
The error message was.

bin/sh Not found

I don’t remember if that was bin/sh or something else, but that don’t work.

Mopman:

Put the output of dmesg in a paste bin somewhere and link us to it (just after booting).

The output: http://dc81.2shared.com/download/3504337/72a05b67/log5453.txt?tsid=20080626-213207-58ea0e2d
But I don’t know how this will help since the command will not work and the package is installed.

Read full topic

item.title: Bootchart! How long does YOUR system take to boot?
item.dc:creator: @llib llib
item.description:
@llib wrote:

[quote=“bowserjr2, post:10, topic:215230”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=282913.msg2298757#msg2298757 date=1214520863]
I believe its a kernel option, so move it up there:

title Ubuntu hardy BOOTCHART root (hd0,1) kernel /boot/vmlinuz-2.6.24-12-generic root=UUID=0df3774e-5eaf-4cbd-9871-5f3a28048ddd ro quiet splash locale=nb_NO init=/sbin/bootchartd initrd /boot/initrd.img-2.6.24-12-generic

[/quote]
I tested it, but the command: bootchart-render did not work.[/quote]

What was the error message that you were given?

Edit:
I’ve dropped it down to 21, I really don’t know what else I can do, I’m practically at a wall here, I’m going through rc.sysinit and removeing checks I don’t need.

I think if I wanted to lose more time I’d have to compile my own kernel with all the modules I need added into it. From what I’ve heard compiling a custom kernel isn’t exactly something you do for fun either.

Although I’ll probably end up doing it anyway >.>

Read full topic

item.title: Bootchart! How long does YOUR system take to boot?
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

I tryed it but it won’t work.

In grub I write this.

title Ubuntu hardy BOOTCHART root (hd0,1) kernel /boot/vmlinuz-2.6.24-12-generic root=UUID=0df3774e-5eaf-4cbd-9871-5f3a28048ddd ro quiet splash locale=nb_NO initrd /boot/initrd.img-2.6.24-12-generic init=/sbin/bootchartd

What did I do wrong?

You should try it…I wanna compare =P

pacman -S bootchart

item.title: Bootchart! How long does YOUR system take to boot?
item.dc:creator: @llib llib
item.description:
@llib wrote:

lol waaay ahead of you Was one of the things I changed first.

# -----------------------------------------------------------------------
# DAEMONS
# -----------------------------------------------------------------------
#
# Daemons to start at boot-up (in this order)
#   - prefix a daemon with a ! to disable it
#   - prefix a daemon with a @ to start it up in the background
#
DAEMONS=(@syslog-ng @cpufreq dbus @wicd @netfs @crond @openntpd @alsa @hal @fam @mysqld @cups @gdm)

It might seem like I have a lot…but it really doesn’t take that long to go through them. To me anyway…

Read full topic
item.source: Bootchart! How long does YOUR system take to boot?

item.title: Bootchart! How long does YOUR system take to boot?
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

You could background some of those daemons Just prefix them with @ in /etc/rc.conf if they are not required for bootup to continue, and they will start in the background.

Read full topic
